{{One source|date=March 2011}} {{Feminism sidebar}} '''State feminism''' is [[feminism]] created or approved by the government of a state or nation. It usually specifies a particular program. The government may, at the same time, prohibit [[non-governmental organization]]s from advocating for any other feminist program.<ref name="FConverge-p223">{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=223}}</ref>
== Turkey == In the 20th century, Turkey's government "preempted feminism".<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=302}}</ref> The [[Turkey|Turkish]] national government's program in the 1920s included mandatory de-[[hijab]]icization (unveiling of women), access for women to more education and work, and political rights for women, all as part of a national effort to emulate some Western cultural characteristics in a Muslim nation.<ref name="FConverge-p223"/>
In the 1980s, [[second-wave feminism]] appeared, among daughters of leading women of Turkey's [[Kemalist ideology|Kemalist]] [[Turkish National Movement|movement]], the women being feminist within the government's definition and leadership.<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=227}}</ref> The state feminism they followed, according to scholar Margot Badran, covered parts of patriarchy with an appearance of Western progressivity.<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=227}}</ref>
== Yemen == In [[South Yemen]], also known as the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen (with the subsequent unification of two Yemens into [[Yemen|one]], the former PDRY is now generally south Yemen), state feminism had little effect on patriarchy and did not have much influence beyond [[Aden]], a port city in the PDRY.<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=260}}</ref> "Women in the south ... seemed to believe their gains would never be rescinded. They behaved as feminists, if by that is meant shaping lives of their choice by accessing the new options offered them. But they did not embrace a feminist ideology or identity, as this was preempted by the state. When the socialist regime collapsed, the fragile gains of state feminism went with it."<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=261}}</ref> "Northern women had acquired an acute gender consciousness and developed practical feminist skills ... but they had no legitimate political space. Southern women had been able to exploit the educational and professional benefits conferred under state feminism, but they did not have the independent ideological space in which to develop a feminism of their own."<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=261}}</ref>
Post-unification Yemen has been analyzed by one author.<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=261}}, citing {{harvp|Carapico|1991|p=15}}</ref>
== Sweden == {{main|Feminism in Sweden}}
== Middle East == In the 1980s and 1990s, "feminist activists and scholars in the Middle East assailed the limits of 'state feminism' and exposed its patriarchal dimensions."<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|p=255}}</ref>
== Communist and socialist regimes == "Sharon Wesoky characterized the relationship of an emergent women's movement to the [Chinese] state as 'symbiotic,' containing elements of both autonomy and dependence, and operating largely within rather than in opposition to party-state institutions."<ref>{{harvp|Hershatter|2007|p=102}}</ref>
{{"'}}State feminisms' have been discredited elsewhere as well [''e.g.'', in China] following the collapse of communist and socialist regimes."<ref>{{harvp|Badran|2009|pp=255, 261}}, citing {{harvp|Yang|1998}}</ref>
== Criticism == "Many feminists ... consider the notion of a state feminism to be an oxymoron."<ref name="FConverge-p223" /> Independent women's movements may be prohibited by the government.<ref name="FConverge-p223" />

{{italic title}} '''''The Listening (In ascolto)''''' is a 2006 movie based on the [[mass surveillance]] operations conducted by the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) with the aid of private corporations. It was Italian director Giacomo Martelli's debut movie and explored the dire consequences that can arise due to excessive corporate influence on a government agency set up for mass surveillance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Spies, Crime and those evil corporations|url=http://likhna.blogspot.in/2007/07/spies-crime-and-those-evil-corporations.html}}</ref>
==Plot== In the late 1990s, the National Security Agency (NSA) and a computer software firm, Wendell Crenshaw work together to implement a surveillance technology, the Echelon, which enables NSA to monitor almost anybody in the world. When classified information about the Echelon system accidentally finds its way into a young woman's hands, a terrible clash occurs in the opinions of a top-executive at Wendell Crenshaw and an NSA operative, the former determined to find out what the lady knows even if it means using violence and the latter, equally determined to save an innocent woman's life<ref>{{cite web|title=The Listening|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/351999/The-Listening/overview}}</ref>
==ECHELON == Making a film specifically on [[ECHELON]] offered the possibility of exploring the issues of interception, violation of privacy, and the interference of corporate interests in matters of national as well as international security simultaneously.<ref>{{cite web|title=WHY MAKE AN ECHELON FILM|url=http://www.docstoc.com/docs/34541111/The-Listening}}</ref>

Overall, [[Africa]] has about 9% of the world's [[fresh water]] resources and 11% of the [[World population|world's population]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/programs/cooperation-in-international-waters-in-africa|title=Cooperation in International Waters in Africa (CIWA)|website=www.worldbank.org|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The United Nations World Water Development Report 2016: Water and Jobs|last=|first=|publisher=UNESCO|year=2016|isbn=978-92-3-100146-8|location=Paris|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> However, there is very significant inter-and intra-annual variability of all [[climate]] and [[water resources]] characteristics, so while some regions have sufficient water,<ref name=":0" /> [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] faces numerous water-related challenges that constrain [[economic growth]] and threaten the livelihoods of its people.<ref name=":0" /> African [[agriculture]] is mostly based on [[rain]]-fed farming, and less than 10% of [[Cultivated land|cultivated]] land in the continent is [[Irrigation|irrigated]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> The impact of [[climate change]] and variability is thus very pronounced.<ref name=":0" /> The main source of [[electricity]] is [[hydropower]], which contributes significantly to the current installed capacity for energy.<ref name=":0" /> Continuing investment in the last decade has increased the amount of power generated.<ref name=":0" />
Solutions to the challenges of water for [[Energy security|energy]] and [[food security]] are hindered by shortcomings in water [[infrastructure]], development, and management capacity to meet the demands of a rapidly growing population.<ref name=":0" /> This is compounded by the fact the Africa has the fastest [[urbanization]] rates in the world.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.worldbank.org/opendata/africa-s-urban-population-growth-trends-and-projections|title=Africa’s urban population growth: trends and projections|last=Rafei|first=Leila|date=2014-10-29|website=The Data Blog|language=en|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> Water development and [[Water resource management|management]] are much more complex due to the multiplicity of trans-boundary water resources ([[river]]s, [[lake]]s and [[aquifer]]s).<ref name=":0" /> Around 75% of sub-Saharan Africa falls within 53 international [[Drainage basin|river basin]] catchments that traverse multiple borders.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> This particular constraint can also be converted into an opportunity if the potential for trans-boundary cooperation is harnessed in the development of the area’s water resources.<ref name=":0" /> A multi-sectoral analysis of the [[Zambezi|Zambezi River]], for example, shows that [[Riparian zone|riparian]] cooperation could lead to a 23% increase in firm energy production without any additional investments.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /> A number of institutional and legal frameworks for transboundary cooperation exist, such as the Zambezi River Authority, the [[Southern African Development Community]] (SADC) Protocol, [[Volta River Authority]] and the [[Nile Basin Commission]].<ref name=":0" /> However, additional efforts are required to further develop political will, as well as the financial capacities and institutional frameworks needed for win-win multilateral cooperative actions and optimal solutions for all riparians.<ref name=":0" />
== Water, jobs and the economy == [[File:GDP Growth in Africa and Developing Countries, 2007 -2017.png|thumb|350px|GDP Growth in Africa and Developing Countries, 2007 -2017]] [[File:Population Growth in Africa, 1950 - 2050.png|thumb|350px|Population Growth in Africa, 1950 - 2050]] Africa has recently undergone its best decade (2005-2015) for [[economic growth]] since the post-[[independence]] period. The growth, however, has neither been inclusive or equitable.<ref name=":0" /> According to the [[World Bank]], [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] growth in sub-Saharan Africa averaged 4.5% in 2014, up from 4.2% in 2013, supported by continuing [[infrastructure]] investment, increased [[agricultural production]] and buoyant services.<ref name=":0" />
[[Africa]]’s population surpassed the 1 billion mark in 2010 and is projected to double by 2050.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1787/aeo-2015-en|title=African Economic Outlook, Books / African Economic Outlook / 2015:Regional Development and Spatial Inclusion|last=AfDB|last2=UNDP|last3=OECD|doi=10.1787/aeo-2015-en}}</ref> Demographically, it is expected to be the fastest growing region in the world with the growth varying depending on sub region.<ref name=":0" /> Furthermore, the growth is skewed to the young and that component of the population that will need jobs is expected to increase rapidly and comprise 910 million out of the projected two billion total population by 2050.<ref name=":0" /> Most of the growth in workforce will be in [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] (about 90%).<ref name=":0" /> Hence, the demand for jobs will be a major policy issue across the continent, which is already experiencing high unemployment and underemployment; moreover, the latter is driving both migration within the region and emigration towards [[Europe]] and other regions.<ref name=":0" />
Job creation for this anticipated growth in population is set to be the major challenge for Africa’s structural economic and social transformation.<ref name=":0" /> It is estimated that in 2015, 19 million young people will be joining the sluggish job market in Sub-Saharan Africa and four million in [[North Africa]].<ref name=":0" /> The demand for jobs is expected to increase to 24.6 million annually in Sub-Saharan Africa and 4.3 million in North Africa by 2030, representing two thirds of global growth in demand for jobs.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> Youth unemployment has been the trigger for uprisings, notably in North Africa, and has led to social and security instability.<ref name=":0" />
The key water-dependent or related sectors with the potential for meeting part of the current and projected demand for jobs in Africa are social services, agriculture, fisheries and aquaculture, [[retail]] and [[hospitality]], [[manufacturing]], [[construction]], [[natural resource]]s exploitation (including [[mining]]) and energy production (including [[Hydropower|hydro]], [[Geothermal energy|geothermal]] and expected [[Hydraulic fracturing|fracking]] for oil and natural gas).<ref name=":0" /> All these sectors depend to a varying extent on the availability of, access to, and reliability of water resources.<ref name=":0" /> Irresponsible water use by some sectors can create short-term employment, but result in negative impacts on the availability of water resources and jeopardize future jobs in other water-dependent sectors.<ref name=":0" /> [[Climate change]], [[water scarcity]] and variability have direct impact on the major sector outputs and thus ultimately on the overall economy of most African countries.<ref name=":0" />
== Jobs in water-dependent sectors == Currently, the most important water-dependent sector in Africa is agriculture, which forms the bedrock of most economies of African states.<ref name=":0" /> Both rain-fed and irrigated agriculture are important job-providing sectors in all African countries.<ref name=":0" />
=== Agriculture === The role of agriculture as the main source of [[employment]] is decreasing in many African countries as a sustained growth in many economies is leading to increasing standards of living, improved education and the occurrence of rapid rural-urban migration of educated youth in search of white collar jobs.<ref name=":0" /> However, for the foreseeable future agriculture will still be a major source of employment, especially in non-oil producing African states.<ref name=":0" /> There is a rising paradox of increasing unemployment in the rapidly urbanizing cities and towns of Africa: labour shortages in rural areas are leading to significant reduction in food production and increased dependence of many African countries on food imports.<ref name=":0" />
Based on [[Food and Agriculture Organization|Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations]] statistics, agriculture was the source of employment for 49% of Africans by 2010 and is a reflection of a gradual decline from 2002 to 2010,which coincides with the period of sustained GDP growth in most African countries.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=The State of World Fisheries and Aquaculture: Opportunities and Challenges|last=|first=|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)|year=2014|isbn=978-92-5-108276-8|location=http://www.fao.org/3/a-i3720e.pdf|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> In spite of this decline, agriculture is expected to create eight million stable jobs by 2020 based on the trends from the McKinsey Global Institute analysis.<ref name=":0" /> If the continent accelerates agricultural development by expanding large scale commercial farming on uncultivated land and shifts production from low-value grain production to more labour-intensive and higher value-added horticultural and bio fuel crops (a good example is [[Ethiopia]]), as many as six million additional jobs could be created continent-wide by 2020.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/insights/africa/africa_at_work|title=Africa at work: Job creation and inclusive growth|website=McKinsey & Company|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> However, such estimates do not take account of the potential displacement or disappearance of existing jobs.<ref name=":0" /> These would need to be carefully assessed in terms of social, economic and environmental impacts in the overall context of responsible agricultural investment.<ref name=":0" />
=== Fisheries === The African fisheries and aquaculture sector employed12.3 million people in 2014 and contributed US $24 billion or 1.26% of the GDP of all African countries, which improved food security and nutrition.<ref name=":0" /> About half of the workers in the sector were fishers and the rest were processors (mainly women) or [[Aquaculture|aquaculturists]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Value of African Fisheries|last=|first=|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)|year=2014|isbn=|location=http://www.fao.org/3/a-i3917e.pdf|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
'''Fisheries and aquaculture contribution to GDP in Africa by sub-sector''' {| class="wikitable" !<ref name=":0" /> !Gross value added (US$ millions) !Contribution to GDP (%) |- !Total GDPs African countries !1,909,514 ! |- !Total fisheries and aquaculture !24,030 !1.26 |- ! ! ! |- |Total inland fisheries |'''4,676''' |'''0.24''' |- |Post-harvest |1,590 |0.08 |- |Local licenses |8 |0 |- | | | |- |'''Total marine artisanal fisheries''' |'''8,130''' |'''0.43''' |- |Marine artisanal fisheries |5,246 |0.27 |- |Post-harvest |2,870 |0.15 |- |Local licenses |13 |0 |- | | | |- |'''Total marine industrial fisheries''' |'''6,849''' |'''0.36''' |- |Marine industrial fishing |4,670 |0.24 |- |Post-harvest |1,878 |0.10 |- |Local licenses |302 |0.02 |- | | | |- |'''Total aquaculture''' |'''2,776''' |'''0.15''' |}
'''Employment by subsector''' {| class="wikitable" !<ref name=":0" /> !Number of employees (thousands) !Share subsector (%) !Share with sector (%) |- |'''Total employment''' |'''12,269''' | | |- | | | | |- |'''Total Inland fisheries''' |'''4,958''' |'''40.4''' | |- |Fishers |3,370 | |68.0 |- |Producers |1,588 | |32.0 |- | | | | |- |'''Total Marine Artisanal Fisheries''' |'''4,041''' |'''32.9''' | |- |Fishers |1,876 | |46.4 |- |Producers |2,166 | |53.6 |- | | | | |- |'''Total Marine Industrial Fisheries''' |'''2,350''' |'''19.2''' | |- |Fishers |901 | |38.4 |- |Producers | | |61.6 |- | | | | |- |'''Aquaculture workers''' |'''920''' |'''7.5''' | |}
=== Manufacturing and industry === Many manufacturing industries in Africa are water-dependent.<ref name=":0" /> The share of jobs is lower than in agriculture, even though the industries cited are considered as water intensive.<ref name=":0" /> In 2011, [[Ghana]]’s economy grew at 14% with the onset of its first production of oil.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Ghana's Economic Performance 2011|last=|first=|publisher=Ghana Statistical Service|year=2012|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> However, in 2015 the growth rate was expected to be only 3.9%.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.africaneconomicoutlook.org/en/country-notes/ghana|title=Ghana {{!}} African Economic Outlook|website=African Economic Outlook|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> This can be attributed to a great extent to the failure to provide the basic water and energy infrastructure to meet the needs of a rapidly growing economy.<ref name=":0" /> Ghana is mainly dependent on the Akosombo hydroelectric dam on the Volta River for electricity.<ref name=":0" /> Due to reduced inflows from low rainfall, the [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric dam]] was operating merely at half of its capacity in 2015.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theafricareport.com/West-Africa/electricity-ghanas-power-crisis-deepens.html|title=Electricity: Ghana's power crisis deepens {{!}} West Africa|last=Ofori-Atta|first=Prince|website=www.theafricareport.com|access-date=2016-11-13}}</ref> This was exacerbated by disruptions mainly in geothermal plants.<ref name=":0" /> In June 2015, all electricity was being rationed at 12 hours on, and 24 hours off.<ref name=":0" /> Though this is extreme, it reinforces the need for water infrastructure to sustain production and jobs in the nascent African economies.<ref name=":0" /> Anecdotal evidence from [[trade union]]s and [[Employment|employers]] in Ghana indicate that tens of thousands of stable jobs were lost in 2015 and the investment climate has turned sour, forcing Ghana to seek [[International Monetary Fund]] macro-economic support again.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Sirte Declaration on the Challenges of Implementing Integrated and Sustainable Development on Agriculture and Water in Africa.|last=|first=|publisher=African Union|year=2004|isbn=|location=http://www.fao.org/nr/water/aquastat/sirte2008/Declaration-Sirte%202004.pdf|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> These policy instruments are underpinned by strategies and programmes, including the New Partnership for African Development Program (NEPAD), Program for Infrastructure Development in Africa (PIDA) and many others, which include the integrated development of Africa’s water resources for socio-economic development and poverty alleviation and eradication.<ref name=":0" /> The [[AU Agenda 2063]], for example, aspires to a prosperous Africa based on inclusive growth and sustainable development.<ref name=":0" /> It specifically aims for an Africa that shall have equitable and sustainable use and management of water resources for socio-economic development, regional cooperation and the environment, and calls for the following action among others.<ref name=":0" /> ''‘Support Young people as drivers of Africa’s renaissance, through investment in their health,education and access to technology, opportunities and capital, and concerted strategies to combat youth unemployment and underemployment.<ref name=":0" /> Encourage exchange and Pan-Africanism among young people through the formation of African Union Clubs in all schools, colleges and universities.<ref name=":0" /> Ensure faster movement on the harmonization of continental admissions, curricula, standards, programmes and qualifications and raising the standards of higher education to enhance the mobility of African youth and talent across the continent by 2025’.''<ref name=":3" />
== Expected future developments == For Africa to be able to meet the [[Sustainable Development Goals]] and maintain the impressive growth rates of the last 10 years, the basic infrastructures of water, electricity and transportation are prerequisites.<ref name=":0" /> Without these basics, the African economies will lose the momentum of the last decade, which will lead to not only loss of direct water jobs, but also jobs in all the other sectors dependent on water.<ref name=":0" /> An illustrative example is the case of Ghana which is often cited as one of the best examples of economic recovery in Africa.<ref name=":0" />
== African Water Policy Framework and impact on jobs == The African Policy Framework for the water sector comprise a series of high-level declarations,resolutions and programmes of action on the development and use of the continent’s water resources for socio-economic development, regional integration and the environment.<ref name=":0" /> These include the [[African Water Vision 2025]] and its Framework of Action, the African Union (AU) [[Extraordinary Summit on Water and Agriculture]], the AU [[Sharm El Sheikh Declaration on Water and Sanitation]], and most importantly, the Agenda 2063 –The Africa We Want.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Sirte Declaration On The Challenges Of Implementing Integrated And Sustainable Development In Agriculture And Water In Africa|last=|first=|publisher=African Union|year=2004|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Africa Water Vision for 2025: Equitable and Sustainable Use of Water for Socioeconomic Development|last=|first=|publisher=African Development Bank Group|year=|isbn=|location=http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Generic-Documents/african%20water%20vision%202025%20to%20be%20sent%20to%20wwf5.pdf|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
These policy instruments are underpinned by strategies and programmes, including the [[New Partnership for African Development Program]] (NEPAD), [[Program for Infrastructure Development in Africa]] (PIDA) and many others, which include the integrated development of Africa’s water resources for socio-economic development and poverty alleviation and eradication.<ref name=":0" />
The AU Agenda 2063, for example, aspires to a prosperous Africa based on inclusive growth and sustainable development.<ref name=":0" /> It specifically aims for an Africa that shall have equitable and sustainable use and management of water resources for socio-economic development, regional cooperation and the environment, and calls for the following action among others.<ref name=":0" /> ''‘Support Young people as drivers of Africa’s renaissance, through investment in their health,education and access to technology, opportunities and capital, and concerted strategies to combat youth unemployment and underemployment.<ref name=":0" /> Encourage exchange and Pan-Africanism among young people through the formation of African Union Clubs in all schools, colleges and universities.<ref name=":0" /> Ensure faster movement on the harmonization of continental admissions, curricula, standards, programmes and qualifications and raising the standards of higher education to enhance the mobility of African youth and talent across the continent by 2025’.''<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4" />
